h i g h l i g h t s
A geopolymer is proposed based on fluidized bed fly ash.
Nano-TiO2 enhances both the early and later compressive strength of geopolymer.
Nano-TiO2 accelerates the formation of geopolymer and refines the microstructure.
Nano-TiO2 improves the carbonation resistance of geopolymer. Nano-TiO2 reduces the drying shrinkage of geopolymer.

Keywords: Geopolymer Fly ash Nano-TiO2 Microstructure Drying shrinkage Carbonation
a b s t r a c t
This study aims to investigate the effects of nano-TiO2 addition on properties of fluidized bed fly ash based geopolymer. Compressive strength, drying shrinkage, carbonation and microstructure of fluidized bed fly ash based geopolymer incorporating nano-TiO2 were reported. Geopolymer specimens were prepared by alkali activation of fluidized bed fly ash in sodium silicate and sodium hydroxide solutions and were cured in microwave radiation environment plus a heat curing period. Properties for geopolymer with and without nano-TiO2 were assessed and compared. The experimental results reveal that the addition of TiO2 enhances both the early and later age compressive strength of geopolymer with the increasing content of nano-TiO2. The strength enhancement effect of nano-TiO2 on geopolymer is more obviously when 5% nano-TiO2 is introduced at 28-day. Microstructure analysis uncovers that the addition of nano-TiO2 promotes the formation of geopolymer and results in compact microstructure with less cracks. The incorporation of nano-TiO2 particles improves the carbonation resistance and reduces the drying shrinkage of geopolymer.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Researches on geopolymer have been carried out for several decades due to two major advantages: low energy consumption and low CO2 emission in the preparation process [1]. Geopolymer materials have an extensive range of applications as a substitute for traditional cements due to their unique properties, such as the ability to withstand elevated temperatures and fire, along with acid and salt resistance compared to those of Portland cement. Geopolymer is prepared by combining supplementary cementitious materials (SCMs) such as metakaolin (produced by calcining kaolin at 650–800 C. The main components are amorphous Al2O3 and SiO2 with high pozzolanic activity. Besides the filling effect, metakaolin reacts with calcium hydroxide, which is one of the hydration products of Portland cement, to form calcium silicate hydrate gels) or industrial by-products with strong alkali solutions such as sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and sodium silicate (in most cases) to form a three-dimensional amorphous aluminosilicate network with properties similar to or better than cement [2–3].
Fly ash, as one of such by-products, is estimated around 750 million tones [4]. As the by-product of coal combustion in thermal power plants, fly ash has an average size of <20 lm and has low to medium bulk density (0.54–0.86 g/cm3), high surface area (300–500 m2/kg) and light texture with spherical in shape and consist of solid spheres, cenospheres, irregular-shaped debris and porous unburnt carbon. In general, fluidized bed fly ash particles are approximately 1–300 lm with irregular shape and it has high contents of lime (CaO), gypsum (CaSO4), and high crystalline phase thus its usage as pozzolanic material is limited. The unique thermal history, featuring low combustion temperatures of 800–950 C, makes fluidized bed fly ash differ greatly in physical and chemical characteristics from coal fly ash, whose typical firing temperatures are 1200–1400 C [5].
At present, only a minor part of this material is utilized (20–30%) on worldwide basis, while the rest is still disposed of in landfills, thus contributing to the pollution of soil, water and air. The environmental impact of fly ash is well known for its massive generation, large usage of land for disposal and short and long term impact on surrounding areas.
Aggressive efforts have been undertaken recently to recycle fly ash in concrete production as geopolymer, which is believed to be the sustainable solution for utilization of fly ash [5–17].
Nano materials are new emerging materials and have been utilized to enhance the mechanical strength and modify the properties of Portland cement, cementitious materials and geopolymer [10,18–19].
With the development of nanotechnology in construction and building materials, the investigations worked on the effects of nano-particles on the properties of cementitious materials were widely conducted in recent years owing to their fine particle size, high reactivity, and specific functional properties [20].
However, nanotechnology applications and advances in the construction and building materials fields have been uneven. Exploitation of nanotechnology in concrete on a commercial scale remains limited with few results successfully converted into marketable products [21].
The commonly used nano materials in cement-based materials are nano-TiO2 [22–28]. However, there are no literatures which discuss the effects of nano-TiO2 on the mechanical strength and microstructure of obtained fly ash based geopolymer. Only Gasca-Tirado et al. [29] described a procedure to ion exchange in geopolymer in order to incorporate photoactive TiO2, but microstructure of geopolymer were not analyzed yet and was still unclear. Yang et al. [30] reported effects of nano-TiO2 on strength,
shrinkage and microstructure of alkali activated slag pastes, however, source material fly ash was not mentioned.
Actually, a few studies have shown that nano-TiO2 can accelerate the early-age hydration of Portland cement, improve compressive and flexural strengths, and enhance the abrasion resistance of concrete [31]. Essawy et al. [32] reported that incorporating 5 wt.% of nano-TiO2 into cement blends gave more desirable physicomechanical properties than others. According to Zhang and Li [33], the pore structure of concretes containing nano-TiO2 is finer than that of concretes containing the same amount of nano-SiO2. The resistance to chloride penetration of concretes containing nano-TiO2 is higher than that of concretes containing the same amount of nano-SiO2. The referred authors also reported that the pore structure refinement increases and the chloride penetration decreases with the content of nano-particles (5 < 3 < 1%). Chen [24] concluded that the addition of nano-TiO2 powders significantly accelerated the hydration rate and promoted the hydration degree of the cementitious materials at early ages. The total porosity of the cement pastes decreased. The compressive strength of the mortar was enhanced, practically at early ages.
Furthermore, for the production of TiO2 based cementitious composites, some authors [34] recommend the use of TiO2 as a solution with the mixing water because it allows for a better dispersion than if it is mixed with the cement. More recently, the addition of nano-TiO2 into cement-based material has won great attention due to its chemical stability, high catalytic activity and low price [35–37].
Importantly, this work will not demonstrate the photocatalysis or the self-cleaning function but emphasizes the mechanical enhancement and microstructure refinement effect of nano-TiO2, for a better dispersion of nano-TiO2 in geopolymer matrix, nanoTiO2 is used for whole geopolymer sample matrix, however, the upper limit content of nano-TiO2 is only 5 wt.%, and the cost is relatively inexpensive. Based on the analysis mentioned above, application prospect of TiO2 geopolymer is still great.
Therefore, this investigation aims to investigate the effects of nano-TiO2 addition on properties including compressive strength, drying shrinkage, carbonation and microstructure of fluidized bed fly ash based geopolymer.
2. Experimental
2.1. Materials
Fluidized bed fly ash was provided by Shenhua Junggar Energy Corporation in Junggar, Inner Mongolia, China. The chemical composition is provided in Table 1.
Scanning electron microscopic study (SEM) of the fly ash reveals some interesting features related to the morphology of fly ash samples. Fig. 1 indicates the geometrical properties, it can be seen that the shape is usually irregular and appears to be porous in a potential state of fragmentation with small and rough particles. Fly ash shows the presence of very fine particles with size of approximately 10 lm being perceived as an agglomeration of particles.
The alkali activator is composed of sodium silicate and sodium hydroxide (99.2% NaOH) in analytical reagent degree. The liquid portions in the mixture are 10 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and sodium silicate (Na2SiO3) with 14.51% Na2O, 33.39% SiO2, and 48.53% H2O. The modulus Ms. (molar ratio of SiO2 to Na2O) of liquid alkali activator was 1.5.
Nano-TiO2 (P25, 75% anatase and 25% rutile) with particle size ranging from 1 nm to 30 nm shown in Fig. 2 was used in this study. The particle size analysis of fly ash and TiO2 were carried out using a laser diffraction particle size analyzer (MASTERSIZER S, Malvern, U.K.). Subsequently each sample was grinded and sieved for 60 min in a sieve shaker. Each of the size fractions obtained was separately analyzed for particle size distribution. Sieve analysis of fly ash and TiO2 reveals that the particle size range varies widely.
The characteristic particle diameters D10, D50 and D90 of fly ash and TiO2 particles have been tabulated in Table 2. A wide variation in particle size was observed in the fly ash and TiO2. The span for fly ash and TiO2 was 3.39 and 2.51, respectively.

2.2. Experimental procedure
In this work, four series of geopolymer specimens (Reference, 1%, 3% and 5% added TiO2) were synthesized by alkaline-activation of fluidized bed fly ash in alkali silicate solutions (modulus of alkaline activator MR = 1.6). The liquid/solid (L/S)
mass ratio is kept constant at 0.5, the liquid comprising water in alkaline solutions and the extra water and the solid materials comprising fly ash. The water and alkaline solution were added and mixed with the solid materials rapidly and continuously.
Fresh geopolymer pastes with varied nano-TiO2 content (replacement level of fly ash, 1%, 3% and 5% by mass) were cast in triplet steel cubes molds with size of 40 40 40 mm3 and rectangular molds with size of 40 40 160 mm3, respectively, and vibrated to remove entrained air bubbles. The molds were then sealed with polyethylene film to prevent moisture loss and set into a microwave radiation environment for 5 min. After initial curing at 40 C for 3 days to prevent cracking due to abrupt loss of water, the samples were released from the molds and were subjected to further curing in a standard condition of 20 C and 95% relative humidity. Sample characterization was conducted on geopolymer paste specimens to evaluate the effects of nano-TiO2 addition on properties of them.
Nano-TiO2 have an obvious effect on the fluidity of cementitious pastes, and therefore, the fluidity test for workability measurement was conducted in accordance to ASTM C230 [38] by using flow table in order to determine the performance of the fresh mixture and to evaluate the effect of nano-TiO2 on the fluidity of geopolymer pastes.
The influences of nano-TiO2 on the mechanical property of geopolymer were evaluated by measuring the compressive strength. Compressive strength tests were performed on cubes with the dimensions of 40 40 40 mm3 using a universal testing machine with a loading capacity of 300 kN using a loading rate of
0.6 MPa/s at ages of 1, 3, 7, 28, 56 and 90 days after casting the samples at 20 C followed by curing at 40 C for 3 days. For each age, six specimens were tested and the mean value of these measurements was reported. The tests were performed by placing the samples between two rigid plates and applying the load with displacement control which is of special importance to adequately perform compressive strength tests. The test was carried out in laboratory conditions at 20 ± 2 C and 60 ± 5% relative humidity at all time.
The influences of nano-TiO2 on the morphological changes of geopolymer were obtained by means of JSM-5610LV scanning electronic microscopy (SEM). The specimens for morphology observation were cut into prisms of about 8 8 2 mm3.
Mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP, AutoPore IV 9500 type) with a maximum pressure of 207 MPa was used to evaluate the porosity and pore size distribution of geopolymer paste incorporating nano-TiO2. The contact angle was 140 and the measurable pore size ranged from about 6 nm to 360 lm. The samples in the shape of pellets of 5 5 5 mm3 in size about 0.8 g sample used for pore structure testing were separated from the crushed specimens. The samples were immerged in ethanol to avoid rehydration immediately after being crushed and dried at about 105 C for 24 h before pore structure test.
Paste specimens of the size 20 20 200 mm3 were prepared for the drying shrinkage test. The specimens were removed from the molds after being cured for 24 h. The prism specimens were installed onto the length comparator apparatus for the length change tests and cured in a room with constant temperature and relative humidity (20 ± 3 C, RH = 90 ± 5%). Length changes of the prism geopolymer specimens incorporating nano-TiO2 were recorded by reading the dial gauge regularly [39]. The shrinkage strain was calculated according to the ASTM standard [40]. The measures continued at different ages as follows: every 24 h for first 7 days; then every 3 days until 28 days.
Carbonation is defined as the natural phenomenon where carbon dioxide from the atmosphere gets absorbed by the alkali activated geopolymer materials with time and promote the formation of carbonates [41].
After 72 h of curing at 40 C, the geopolymer specimens with and without nanoTiO2 were subjected to accelerated carbonation in an environmental chamber at a temperature of 24 ± 5 C and relative humidity of 65 ± 5% for 3 d, 7 d, 28 d, 90 d and 180 d. A CO2 gas tank was used to pass the gas inside the chamber and was tightly sealed to prevent leakage. The CO2 concentration is kept at 20.0%.
In order to quantify the evolution of carbonation with time after exposure of the specimens inside the CO2 environment, the carbonation front depth was determined by means of phenolphthalein spray test, which changes colour and thus indicates the geopolymer paste areas with a pH below 9, which is the region where carbonation occurs.
Phenolphthalein is a pH indicator which changes progressively from pinkfuchsia to colourless when the pH drops from 10 to 8.3 [42]. The specimens dedicated to the phenolphthalein test were split in two half-cube. After splitting the specimens, the freshly split surface was cleaned and sprayed with a phenolphthalein pH indicator. The indicator used was a phenolphthalein 1% ethanol solution with 1 g phenolphthalein and 90 mL 95.0 V/V% ethanol diluted in water to 100 mL. The carbonation depth was determined at each test age in twelve points along the 40 mm-side length exposed surface. The average of twelve points readings is used to define the carbonation depth XC as shown in Fig. 3.

sections.heading: 3.1. Compressive strength
sections.text:
The compressive strength of reference geopolymer and geopolymer with varied nano-TiO2 content at different ages is given in Fig. 4. It can be seen that the addition of TiO2 enhances both the early and later compressive strength of geopolymer. The compressive strength of TiO2 group was approximately 7.1%, 3.0%, 4.4%, 5.4%, 4.7% and 3.8% higher than those of reference group when 1% nano-TiO2 was introduced at 1 d, 3 d, 7 d, 28 d, 56 d and 90 d, respectively. However, strength enhancement effect of nanoTiO2 on geopolymer pastes is more obviously when more nanoTiO2 was incorporated, the compressive strength of TiO2 group was approximately 51%, 17.4%, 17.8%, 22.0%, 22.0% and 19.2% higher than those of reference group when 5% nano-TiO2 was introduced at 1 d, 3 d, 7 d, 28 d, 56 d and 90 d, respectively.
The compressive strength of geopolymer increases very fast before 28 days andbecomes slowly after this period. Comparingwith the later ages (56 days and 90 days) strength development, it shows that the contribution of nano-TiO2 on the early age (before 28 days) strength improvement is obvious. The development degree increases rapidly from1 days to3 days, however, the developmentof compressive strength from 3 days to 7 days was much less than that from 7 days to 28 days. Curing conditions influence the compressive strength development. After initial curing at 40 C for 3 days, the compressive strength increase rapidly before 3 days as the high temperature curing improves the geopolymerization process, after this period, strength develops slowly due tomoisture loss ad 40 C. After 7 days of curing, however, further curing in a standard condition of 20 C and 95% relative humidity recovers the moisture needed for the geopolymerizationprocess, and therefore, a rapid strengthdevelopment can be observed from7 days to 28 days. After 28 days of curing, the compressive strength of geopolymer development becomes slowly as geopolymerization nearly completed before this period.
The comparable strength development of geopolymers with 1% and 3% nano-TiO2 to that of the reference samples reveals that a certain amount of nano-TiO2 is needed for obtaining a desired improvement of the compressive strength, and this compiles well with other’s work [43–44,24].

sections.heading: 3.2. Micro morphology
sections.text:
The crystalline phase composition of TiO2-added geopolymer and reference geopolymer were identified using XRD technique
of Bruker-AXS D8 Advance Diffractometer with copper radiation and a LynxEye position sensitive detector. The data was collected from 5 to 70 2hwith a nominal step size of 0.015 and a collection time of 0.7 s per step. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of TiO2added geopolymer and reference geopolymer are shown in Fig. 5. In reference geopolymer, typical peaks of anatase (A), quartz (Q) and mullite (M) phases are detected. On the other hand, XRD patterns of geopolymer with addition of TiO2 indicate that the crystalline phases consist of anatase (A), quartz (Q), albite (AB) and mullite (M). It is shown in Fig. 5 that the mineral types and the relative magnitude of the peaks of geopolymer pastes with or without nano-TiO2 are comparable, but differences of the individual peak intensity are seen and the increment of the intensity of crystal structure can also be seen, demonstrating that more hydrates are formed. The above results illustrate the hydration acceleration effect of nano-TiO2.
Microstructures for reference group and TiO2 groups were observed by SEM when 5% nano-TiO2 was introduced. The typical pictures taken under SEM are shown in Fig. 6.
At 3 days, differences in microstructure between the reference geopolymer and TiO2 group are clearly observed. The structure of TiO2 group (Fig. 6(b)) is much denser than reference group (Fig. 6 (a)). Meanwhile, it can be seen that the incorporation of TiO2 considerably reduces the width and number of micro cracks in geopolymer matrix. At 7 days, the microstructures of both groups are much denser. For reference group, voids form across the matrix. The structure of TiO2 group (Fig. 6(d)) is more homogeneous than that in reference group (Fig. 6(c)). Up to 28 days, geopolymer for both groups have developed into solid mass at micro scale. The structure of TiO2 group (Fig. 6(f)) is much denser than reference group (Fig. 6(e)). As far as the results from SEM are concerned, the addition of nano-TiO2 into geopolymer results in much denser microstructure with less cracks. This result is consistent with the enhanced strength of TiO2 group specimens (see Fig. 4).

sections.heading: 3.3. Pore structure
sections.text:
Quantitative results on the pore structure of geopolymer with and without nano-TiO2 were obtained from the MIP measurements. The effects of nano-TiO2 incorporating on pore size distribution and porosity of geopolymer at 28 days were evaluated and the results are showed in Fig. 7. It can be clearly noticed that the pores of geopolymer are refined by the addition of nano-TiO2. Compared to the reference group, the TiO2 group has relatively
lower total porosity (Fig. 7(a)). A decrease trend of the accumulative pore volume can be seen when more nano-TiO2 is incorporated. The nano-particles seem to act as effective fillers. 0.125 mL/g, 0.087 mL/g, 0.072 mL/g, 0.069 mL/g of the cumulative intrusion volume are seen when 0%, 1%, 3% and 5% nano-TiO2 are added at 28 d, respectively. 93 nm, 42 nm, 41 nm, 36 nm of the most probable pore size corresponding to the highest peak value (Fig. 7(b)) are seen when 0%, 1%, 3% and 5% nano-TiO2 are added, respectively.
With hydration continues, the conglomerations containing the nano-particles as nucleus expand and fill up the pore space around them gradually. The presence of these ‘‘nuclei’’ significantly accelerates the hydration rate. Therefore, the hydrates accumulate rapidly and grow outwards into the water and fill the voids, resulting in the decrease in porosity [24]. From the above results and analysis it can be concluded that the seeding effect (as can be seen in Fig. 5 as mentioned above) of nano-TiO2 promotes the formation of geopolymer, which finally leads to a more compact structure. This result is consistent with the enhanced compressive strength (see Fig. 4) and dense microstructure (see Fig. 6).
Geopolymers with addition of nano-TiO2 have a relatively higher strength when compared with Reference sample (see Fig. 4). This is also confirmed by MIP tests, which shows the total porosities of the Reference samples are significantly higher than the porosities of the nano-TiO2 added geopolymers (see Fig. 7). Additionally, a more denser microstructure can be observed in nano-TiO2 added geopolymers (see Fig. 6). The MIP results (in Fig. 7) correlate well with the compressive strength (in Fig. 4) and microstructure (in Fig. 6).

sections.heading: 3.4. Formation and simulation of microstructure
sections.text:
MIP and SEM tests have been utilized to assess the twodimensional microstructure of geopolymer with and without nano-TiO2 particles from the experimental aspect. For the simulation of the reaction processes and the formation of the threedimensional microstructure in geopolymer system, the numerical model HYMOSTRUC was developed [45].
In this model, the degree of hydration was simulated as a function of the particle size distribution, the chemical composition of geopolymer materials, the liquid/solid ratio and the reaction temperature. In this computer digitized format of HYMOSTRUC, the raw solid particles including TiO2 particles were modelled as digitized spheres randomly distributed in a three-dimensional body and the hydrating geopolymer were simulated as growing spheres.
In this model, the geopolymer particles are modelled as spheres of different diameters. TiO2 and fly ash are not regular spheres, and this may be the limitation of this simulation model. However, the hydration proceeds at the particle/water interface and the hydration products grow around the original particles in this model is true when geopolymerization occurs.
The microstructure formation and development in geopolymer with different content of nano-TiO2 particles is schematically presented in Fig. 8, in which geopolymer samples show a homogenous microstructure with reaction products evenly distributed in the matrix. Some large cavities form and are seemed as ‘‘isolated” by aluminosilicate gels.
The initial reference geopolymer particles without nano-TiO2 (Fig. 8(a)) are randomly distributed in a three-dimensional body at very early age (2 h). Few products form at 2 h when 1% and 3% nano-TiO2 particles were incorporated as can be seen from Fig. 8 (b) and Fig. 8(c), respectively, however, a little amount of products could be observed at this time when 5% nano-TiO2 particles were incorporated as can be seen from Fig. 8(d)). With the reaction time increases, plenty of hydration products fill the voids in the geopolymer matrix and the microstructure becomes denser at
7 days with increasing content of nano-TiO2 particles as can be seen from Fig. 8(e) to Fig. 8(h), which can also be proved from the SEM and MIP results. Obviously, large amount of outer hydration products form at longer ages 90 days and the microstructure at this age from Fig. 8(i) to Fig. 8(l) can be observed to be much denser and only a few voids exist in the matrix.
Nano-TiO2 will influence on the hydration speed and degree of geopolymer materials and the formation of hydrated products because of the nucleation and nano-filling. As can be seen from the numerical model of microstructure of different geopolymer pastes, the size and amount of un-reacted particles decreases with increasing content of nano-TiO2 regardless of curing ages and the size and amount of hydrated products increases for the geopolymer pastes with increasing content of nano-TiO2. Importantly, the porosity decreases and much denser microstructure can be observed with increasing content of nano-TiO2.
Based on the compressive strength result (Fig. 4) combined with experimental microstructure analysis (Figs. 5–7) and computer digitized format of microstructure (Fig. 8), strength enhancement of geopolymer with addition of TiO2 can be explained from
the following aspects. Firstly, TiO2 particles are generally several to ten nanometers in diameter smaller than fly ash significantly (Fig. 2 and Table 2), therefore, a replacement of fly ash by TiO2 particles promotes porosity refinement and a reduction of the porosity as well as denser microstructure can be observed (Figs. 6 and 7). Those fine particle materials contribute to the compaction of the geopolymer matrix.
Due to micro aggregates filling effect mentioned above, fine particles of TiO2 particles bridge the gap between inner particles of geopolymer, which makes the paste denser. Meanwhile, the total pore volume of decreases significantly, and pore size distribution shifts to the small pore diameter portion and leads to the optimization of the microstructure (Figs. 6 and 7) and hence the high strength increasing rate.
Furthermore, phase composition as shown in Fig. 5 indicates that in reference geopolymer, typical peaks of anatase (A), quartz (Q) and mullite (M) phases are detected. On the other hand, XRD patterns of geopolymer with addition of TiO2 indicate that the crystalline phases consist of anatase (A), quartz (Q), albite (AB) and mullite (M). The mineral types and the relative magnitude of
the peaks of geopolymer pastes with or without nano-TiO2 are comparable, but differences of the individual peak intensity are seen and the increment of the intensity of crystal structure can also be seen, demonstrating that more hydrates are formed. The above results illustrate the hydration acceleration effect and seeding effect of nano-TiO2.
Importantly, the alkaline reactivity of fly ash samples was determined according to Chapelle test described in [46], 1 g of fly ash was mixed with 1 g of Ca(OH)2 and 100 ml of boiled water. The suspension was boiled for 16 h and the free Ca(OH)2 was determined by means of sucrose extraction and titration with a HCl solution. The pozzolanic activity was 57.5% for fly ash. Higher alkaline reactivity of fly ash also leads to higher strength even though the high value of the ignition loss indicated in Table 1.
Finally, nano-TiO2 will influence on the hydration speed and degree of geopolymer materials and the formation of hydrated products because of the nucleation and nano-filling, which can be seen from the numerical model of microstructure of different geopolymer pastes in Fig. 8, the size and amount of un-reacted particles decreases with increasing content of nano-TiO2 regardless of curing ages and the size and amount of hydrated products increases for the geopolymer pastes with increasing content of nano-TiO2. The porosity decreases and much denser microstructure can be observed with increasing content of nano-TiO2.
Meanwhile, in previously reported findings, Hassan Noorvand et al. [43] found that 1.5% nano TiO2 increased the strength of reference samples up to 10%, 18% and 17% at 7, 28 and 90 days. They
also explained this phenomenon from physical filling and interlocking effects of nano TiO2 leaded to the decreasing of the porosity of and the improvement of the microstructure of the matrix, and nanosized particles of TiO2 with high surface energy accelerated early hydration. The explanation can also been interpreted in this work as mentioned above. Chen [24] also reported that the compressive strength of the mortars was significantly improved at all ages due to the addition of nano-TiO2 with smaller particle size. Essawy et al. [32] concluded that nano-sized particles acted as nucleating agents during the hydration of cement and the hydrated products accumulate and precipitate in the water filled capillary pores, which leaded to increase of the compressive strength. Zhang et al. [20] also concluded that the increase of the compressive strength could be accounted for the greater contribution of the hydration acceleration effect of nano-particles. They revealed that the 28-day compressive strength the 5% nano-TiO2-added cement mortar was 20% greater than that of the control.
Based on the analysis from the findings in this work and the previously findings mentioned above, 5% nano-TiO2 addition geopolymer with higher strength improvement was obtained.

sections.heading: 3.5. Fluidity
sections.text: The workability of fly ash geopolymer blended with nano-TiO2 was measured by using a flow table test to check the consistency of fresh mortars before casting. Fig. 9 depicts the flow diameter measured and recorded. It is clearly observed that reference sample without nano-TiO2 indicates 215 mm flow diameter whereas it is 198 mm for 1% of nano-TiO2 addition geopolymer. It can be seen that the flow diameter decreases as the nano-TiO2 content increases to 3% and 5% resulting in a diameter of 169 and 148 mm respectively. It can be concluded that nano-TiO2 addition influences the fluidity of geopolymer especially when more than 3% of nano-TiO2 is added.

sections.heading: 3.6. Drying shrinkage
sections.text:
The results provided in Fig. 10 indicate the influences of nanoTiO2 particles on the drying shrinkage of geopolymer pastes. It can be noticed that the evolution of drying shrinkage of geopolymer paste specimens before and after the addition of nano-TiO2 particles presents the similar trend. It can be seen that the reference specimen exhibits a higher shrinkage value to those with nano-TiO2 particles especially the 5% TiO2 incorporated specimen. The shrinkage reducing effect of TiO2 addition can be observed obviously after 5 days for 1% TiO2 incorporated specimen, however, for 3% and 5% TiO2 incorporated specimen, shrinkage reducing effect can be seen only after 2 days.
According to previous published paper [47], the drying shrinkage of cementitious materials may be due to a higher volume of mesopores, which causes a higher capillary stress by the water meniscus developed in the capillary pores of the paste, resulting in a higher level of drying shrinkage [48]. Results from SEM combined with MIP reveals that nano-TiO2 particles present pore refine effect on geopolymer specimens, which results in much denser microstructure and lower shrinkage value.

sections.heading: 3.7. Carbonation
sections.text:
The carbonation phenomenon in fly ash geopolymer is a critical aspect of durability that needs to be studied, as it seems to be one of the most detrimental durability aspects of these materials.
The results provided in Fig. 11 uncover the influences of nanoTiO2 particles on the carbonation resistance of different geopolymer pastes. It can be concluded that the change of the carbonation depth of geopolymer paste specimens before and after the addition

(c) 3% TiO2-2 hours (d) 5% TiO2-2 hours
(e) Referene-7 days (f) 1% TiO2-7 days
Fig. 8. Formation of the microstructure in geopolymer at various curing times. ( un-reacted particles inner products outer products pores).
of nano-TiO2 particles is negligible at 3 days. It can be seen that the reference specimens exhibit higher carbonation depth values to those with nano-TiO2 particles especially the 5% TiO2 incorporated specimen after 7 days. The carbonation resistance improving effect of TiO2 addition can be observed obviously after 28 days. The carbonation depths at 180 days after the addition of 1%, 3% and 5% nano-TiO2 particles are only 77%, 62% and 42% to the reference specimens, respectively.

[50] and sodium carbonate products identified by Bernal et al. [51]. In these fly ash geopolymers, nanostructural changes and fully carbonated samples lost their loading capacity and could be easily destroyed by hand. Obviously, combined with results of SEM, MIP and microstructure simulation, it can be concluded that the incorporation of nano-TiO2 particles refines the microstructure and improves the carbonation resistance of geopolymer.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
This study intends to broaden the application of nano-TiO2 in fluidized bed fly ash based geopolymer. Geopolymer specimens were prepared by alkali activation of fluidized bed fly ash. Compressive strength, drying shrinkage, carbonation and microstruc-
ture of geopolymer incorporating varies content of nano-TiO2 were reported. The results are summarized below:
(1). The addition of TiO2 enhances both the early and later compressive strength of geopolymer. The strength enhancement effect is much obviously at longer ages when 5% nano-TiO2 is introduced. The compressive strength of geopolymer increases very fast before 28 days and slowly at longer ages.
(2). The addition of nano-TiO2 promotes the formation of geopolymer and results in denser microstructure with less cracks. The pores of geopolymer are also refined by the addition of nano-TiO2. In the computer digitized format of HYMOSTRUC, the size and amount of unreacted particles decreases and large amount of outer hydration products can be observed at longer ages.
(3). The shrinkage reducing effect of TiO2 addition can be observed obviously after 5 days for 1% TiO2 incorporated specimen, however, for 3% and 5% TiO2 incorporated specimen, shrinkage reducing effect can be seen only after 2 days. The carbonation resistance improving effect of TiO2 addition can be observed obviously only after 28 days. Combined with results of SEM, MIP and microstructure simulation, the incorporation of nano-TiO2 particles refines the microstructure and improves the carbonation resistance and reduces the drying shrinkage of geopolymer.
(4). The microstructure results correlate well with the mechanical properties and durability aspects
